items.title: fluent 8
items.body: Fixes #457

items.title: config initializable / provider cleanup
Router polish
items.body:
Features:
- [x] Fallback routes, ie: `path/to/*` will match `path/to`, `path/to/a`, `path/to/b`, `path/to/anything/here/will/fall/back`
- [x] Support `path/to/:slug`, `path/to/*`, and `path/to/concrete`
- [x] Fully generic branches and underlying router. We can swap out responder and use branches completely dissociated from itself.
- [x] 2x performance increase
- [x] Wildcard methods. Right now, we have to register for each HTTPMethod. Now we can register underlying method `*` and it will call if existing method, ie: if I have `* path/to/thing` and `GET path/to/thing` a GET request will match corresponding GET. All other methods will fallback to `*`.
- [x] HTTP / Engine / Everything agnostic
- [x] Branches 100% cov

items.title: Engine 4
items.body: Update to qutheory/engine 0.4.

items.title: fix slashes in routing
items.body:
Allows syntax like:

``` swift
drop.get("foo/bar") { req in ... }
```

items.title: Changed prep type to Entity to allow pivots to be prepared.
items.body: Fixes vapor/fluent#61

items.title: Cache
items.body:
Adds cache support to Vapor which can be powered by Fluent, Memory, or anything conforming to the CacheProtocol like Redis.

Fixes #259 

Todo:
- [ ] Add tests
- [ ] Move `VaporRedis` to separate package

items.title: Routing fixes
items.body: Fixes a bug where middleware impeded routing.

items.title: view caching
items.body: Speeds up views by caching files so that they are not loaded from disk every request.

items.title: Cookies module + testing
items.body:
This branch was originally supposed to integrate turnstile but it turned out good cookie support was necessary.

A module dedicated to cookie parsing and serializing has been created and has 100% test coverage now.

items.body:
Done
- [x] 100% cov
- [x] Simplified Droplet usage as just node
- [x] No longer auto-loads undesignated CLI args

items.title: bundled middleware public access
items.body: Some of the bundled middleware did not have public access level so it was difficult to opt-in/opt-out at the user's discretion. Included a test to check that bundled middleware (well the ones in drop.middleware by default) is publicly accessible.

items.title: Also merge View of Provider
items.body:
In the recent refactoring the .merge function wasn't brought up to speed, so view renderers weren't getting merged. This fixes it.

/cc @tannernelson

items.title: JSON 0.6 + Engine 0.7
items.body: Fixes #515

items.title: Added new up-to-date tutorial written on Septembers 1th 2016
items.body: It's actually a tutorial written and published on my own. I will continuously improve it, add new steps getting deeper very soon. My goal is to keep every single step just up-to-date as vapor evolves, so there's a tutorial out there you can rely on it will work right away :)! My idea is to provide tutorial-versioning, so you can switch between vapor versions on my site and according to the chosen one, the right steps are provided to get vapor run in that version (starting with version 16) :)

items.title: Detect file, function and line of a log call
items.body:
Currently just the log level and the message are used for logging based
on the given protocol. Where the logging call is actually happening is
ignored which makes debugging much harder.

To fix that, I changed the protocol and all files that consume it in
the main Vapor project to get the file, function and line of a log call
by using magic Swift variables. These values can then be used for a
more sophisticated logging and can be ignored if not used.

The position of these variables is important to get the correct
position of the log call in the source code.

items.title: sessions and middleware
items.body:
Adds more configurability to middleware and moves sessions to its own module.

Fixes #502 #559 #419 #579

Todo:
- [x] Add more tests
- [x] Discuss `vapor-auth` being separate cookie token
- [x] ~~Move middleware to HTTP server~~ (would break other stuff)
- [x] Support client _and_ server middleware in `middleware.json`
### Sessions

Sessions are set like so:

``` swift
drop.get("set") { req in
    try req.session().data["foo"] = "bar"
    try req.session().data["bar"] = "baz"
    return "set"
}
```

and fetched like so:

``` swift
drop.get("get") { req in
    return try req.session().data["foo"]?.string ?? "fail"
}
```

They rely on Node under the hood.

There is a `MemorySessions` and `CacheSessions` conformance out of the box. Memory uses an array and cache uses an underlying `CacheProtocol` to store the sessions. Notably, this could use the same `CacheProtocol` as `Auth`, but it _does not_ use the same cookie.

I think leaving this separate allows for better modularity, especially since Turnstile replicates some of the functionality of `SessionsProtocol`.

Maybe these will be separate modules some day that can be optional. Probably best they don't rely on each other.
### Middleware

Middleware is  now a `let` constant on Droplet and is supplied as a `[String: Middleware]` dict to the init or through providers. This allows for the provided middleware (both from the init and from providers) to be selected at will from the `Config/middleware.json` file. This will be great for choosing different middleware for different environments and also making it clear which middleware is on by default.

Should no `Config/middleware.json` file be present, all provided middleware (both from the init and from providers) will be enabled.

The merging of middleware is unique for providers. Every other property on providers will throw an error if provided by more than one provider. Obviously middleware works a bit differently. Instead, an error will only be thrown if different providers provide a middleware with the same name key.

Additionally, since we have the middleware at init time now, we can pass it directly to the `HTTP.Server` when initialized. That let's Engine (well tested now) handle the middleware logic.
